[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Proxy] [Proxy chaining] Can attackers chain multiple proxies together to obscure their origin or bypass rate limiting? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Proxy] [Transparent proxy detection] Is there protection against transparent proxies that might modify traffic without explicit configuration? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Proxy] [Proxy protocol confusion] Can the HTTP CONNECT protocol be confused with SOCKS or other proxy protocols, causing unexpected behavior? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Config] [Default values security] Are the default values in TcpTransport::default() secure, or do they need explicit configuration to be production-safe? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Config] [Config validation] Is there validation that ttl, nodelay, and buffer sizes are within acceptable ranges when TcpTransport is constructed? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Config] [Config persistence] Are configuration changes properly persisted across reconnections, or can config be reset to insecure defaults? (Low)
[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [IPv6] [IPv6 zone ID] Are IPv6 zone identifiers (e.g., fe80::1%eth0) properly handled in address parsing and connection establishment? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [IPv6] [IPv4-mapped IPv6] Can IPv4-mapped IPv6 addresses (::ffff:192.0.2.1) bypass IpFilter restrictions or cause confusion in address handling? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [IPv6] [Dual-stack binding] When binding to IPv6 addresses, does the code properly handle dual-stack sockets, or can IPv4 connections be unintentionally accepted? (Medium)
[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Resources] [Socket leaks] Are sockets properly closed in all error paths, or can exceptions or early returns cause socket leaks? (Medium)
[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Resources] [FD exhaustion] Can attackers exhaust file descriptor limits by causing many failed connection attempts? (High)
[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Resources] [Port exhaustion] Can outbound connections exhaust ephemeral ports, preventing new connections from being established? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Testing] [IPv6 test coverage] Do the tests at lines 416-492 adequately cover IPv6 scenarios, or are there IPv6-specific vulnerabilities untested? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Testing] [Proxy test coverage] Are there tests for connect_via_proxy() with malicious proxy responses, or could proxy-related vulnerabilities go undetected? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Testing] [Error path coverage] Do tests cover all error paths (connection refused, timeout, DNS failure), or could error handling bugs remain hidden? (Low)
[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Timing] [Connection timing] Can attackers measure connection establishment times to infer internal network topology or validator state? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Timing] [DNS resolution timing] Can DNS resolution time measurements leak information about validator network configuration or reveal internal IP ranges? (Low)
[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Race] [Bind race] In listen_on(), is there a race between binding and listening where another process could bind to the same port? (Low)
[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Race] [Connect race] Can concurrent dial() calls to the same address cause unexpected connection state or resource contention? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Validator] [Eclipse attacks] Can attackers use DNS or proxy manipulation to eclipse honest validators by controlling their peer connections? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Validator] [Sybil attacks] Can attackers create many connections from different source IPs/ports to exhaust validator resources or influence peer selection? (High)

[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Validator] [Consensus message routing] Can TCP-level connection manipulation affect consensus message delivery, causing timing issues or message loss? (Critical)
[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Validator] [Network partition] Can targeted TCP RST or FIN packets partition the validator network, breaking consensus quorum? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Platform] [Windows behavior] Do TCP socket options behave consistently on Windows vs Linux, or could platform differences create security gaps? (Low)
[File: aptos-core/network/netcore/src/transport/tcp.rs] [Platform] [macOS limits] On macOS, are file descriptor and socket option limits different, potentially causing unexpected behavior? (Low)
